Voss.synopsis: Voss' aftermath after the scene with Raphael and himself.
Voss.how_to_trigger: Find Raphael at the SC upstairs and play through VossScene first. The speak with Voss again. Or use oe RaphaelTango_IntroDone to skip that and get to this dialog immediatelly

AD_RaphaelVoss.synopsis: AD between Raphael and Voss in the devil's room in Sharess Caress.
AD_RaphaelVoss.how_to_trigger: BGO_Main_A, Sharess Caress. Make sure Voss is alive through Debug Book and teleport at Raphael's room entrance.

AD_RaphaelRetreats.synopsis: AD that Raphael plays in Sharess Caress just before he poofs away in a huge flame and teleports to the House of Hope, after the player dealt too much damage to him.
AD_RaphaelRetreats.how_to_trigger: BGO_Main_ASharess Caress, upper floor, Raphael's roomAttack Raphael, until he'll has less than 50% of his hitpoints.

Emperor_AfterRaphael.synopsis: Emperor resumes psychic connection to player once Raphael is done with them and has offered them his deal.
Emperor_AfterRaphael.how_to_trigger: Find Raphael at the SC upstairs and enter his room and finish the initial conversation

ThreeWay_VossScene.synopsis: The introduction dialog with Voss, where Raphael dismisses him to then talk to the player in private.
ThreeWay_VossScene.how_to_trigger: BGO_Main_A, Sharess' CaressVoss alive, Find Raphael at the SC upstairs and enter his room

PAD_MessengerReaction.synopsis: At the Wyrm's Crossing entrance there's a Raphael's messenger. He addresses to one of the characters and when he gets closer to the characters, he slips the Raphael's letter to the inventory. After that the messenger poofs away, and that triggers this PAD as a reaction on the letter being added to the inventory
PAD_MessengerReaction.how_to_trigger: 1. BGO_Main_A2. Move closer to the tiefling there

AD_RaphaelAttacked.synopsis: AD that is played when Raphael is attacked by the player while in Sharess Caress. Raphael then just teleports the player away from his room.
AD_RaphaelAttacked.how_to_trigger: BGO_Main_ASharess Caress, upper floor, Raphael's roomAttack Raphael

Raphael.synopsis: Stub for Raphael after the "Tango" scene, where Raphael suggested the contract to the player. The player may reconsider later on.
Raphael.how_to_trigger: Find Raphael at the SC upstairs and play through the scene first. Then speak with him again.

Warlock.synopsis: Korrilla dialog in Sharess Caress taproom standing next to a bar. "You enter Sharess' Caress and find Korrilla Hearthflame having a drink with Hoots the bartender. "
Warlock.how_to_trigger: BGO_Main_A, 19; 44; 84Talk to Korrilla near the bar.

AD_WarlockAfterRaphael.synopsis: After players talk to Raphael in Sharess Caress, Korrilla will want to talk with them

Raphael_SoloScene.synopsis: Raphael offers his deal to free Orpheus - no Voss variant. Voss is either dead or not present currently
Raphael_SoloScene.how_to_trigger: Either ingore Voss in Sharess Caress Taproom or use oe RaphaelTango_Reset_VossDead, find Korrilla in SC, talk to her, let her lead you to Raph's room and then enter the room

Voss_4.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_4.text: Follow me to the taproom. We will speak there.

Voss_13.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_13.text: I will be waiting beneath the city.

Voss_82.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_82.text: Find me when you've taken the Hammer. You will be well-rewarded.

Voss_29.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_29.text: Go, talk to Raphael. I'll wait here.

Voss_65.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_65.text: Raphael knew how to free Prince Orpheus - and you made him an enemy.

Voss_38.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_38.text: My people's freedom is at hand. I can feel it.

Voss_52.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_52.text: Tell me, Lae'zel. Tell me you took the devil's deal. Tell me you will free Gith's heir.

Voss_20.speaker: Player
Voss_20.text: I have the Hammer. I stole it from Raphael's lair.

Voss_78.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_78.text: So you lied to me. In spite of all our progress together, still you would abuse my trust.

Voss_94.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_94.text: The Hammer... how can it be that you came to possess it... Was it Raphael?

Voss_110.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_110.text: So you made the deal with Raphael after all. Fool.

Voss_54.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_54.text: So quick to share it with him... this is not wise, Lae'zel.

Voss_46.text: So quick to share it with him... this is not wise.

Voss_39.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_39.text:
'The Prince of the Comet is not dead.
The Prince of the Comet will come again.
The Prince of the Comet will liberate us from the lich queen's tyranny.'

Voss_79.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_79.text: Can it be - will the mighty Prince Orpheus soon illuminate the Astral Plane?

Voss_60.speaker: Lae'zel
Voss_60.text: Gith's son will soon ride against Vlaakith, Voss. And I will follow him into battle.

Voss_75.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_75.text: And you will wield the greatest gift Mother Gith ever granted her dauntless children.
Voss_75.context: CinematicNodeContext: Voss leans forward to give player a silver sword, doesn't need to be shown beyond a lean.

Voss_109.speaker: Lae'zel
Voss_109.text: I will carry it for the honour of Gith, the great liberator - and her unforgotten son.

Voss_59.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_59.text: Among the githyanki, one gift is esteemed above all others. The silver sword.

Voss_31.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_31.text: Take it. Wield it in honour of Gith, the great liberator - and her unforgotten son.
Voss_31.context: CinematicNodeContext: Voss leans forward to give player a silver sword, doesn't need to be shown beyond a lean.

Voss_34.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_34.text: Istik, now that you have the Hammer you must find a way to enter the Astral Prism.

Voss_47.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_47.text: Once inside, smash Orpheus' bonds. His cry will shake the planes, and I will fly to your aid.

Voss_5.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_5.text: The Prince of the Comet will sear the heavens again. Let the lich queen tremble!

Voss_137.text: Think again. I will not permit your entry.

Voss_114.speaker: Player
Voss_114.text: You need to let me into the Prism.

Voss_7.speaker: Player
Voss_7.text: Is there any way I can convince you?

Voss_11.speaker: Player
Voss_11.text: I'll find a way to free Orpheus from your clutches.

Voss_9.text: Even if you could, you would relinquish your mind to the elder brain in so doing.

Voss_101.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_101.text: Questions, istik? You seem to be lost in thought.

Voss_96.speaker: Player
Voss_96.text: Getting into the Astral Prism will be complicated.

Voss_37.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_37.text: Yes. But you will meet this challenge, as you've met so many others.

Voss_0.speaker: Player
Voss_0.text: Orpheus sensed the tadpole before, and his guard attacked. Won't he attack if we free him?

Voss_17.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_17.text: The Prince of the Comet aches for githyanki liberation more than he abhors ghaik.

Voss_26.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_26.text: He might seethe when you free him. He might gnash his teeth and slander your name.

Voss_127.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_127.text: But he will see reason. I promise you.

Voss_53.speaker: Player
Voss_53.text: I took the bargain. I will free Orpheus at the first chance.

Voss_57.speaker: Player
Voss_57.text: I took the bargain. I will free Orpheus at the first chance.

Voss_126.speaker: Narrator
Voss_126.text: *Lae'zel remains quiet in the face of your lie - but her eyes betray her contempt.*

Voss_112.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_112.text: Are my wounds not deep enough, that you would salt them with lies?

Voss_18.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_18.text: Orpheus will be free. There is no cost too high to unshackle my people!

Voss_80.speaker: Player
Voss_80.text: Don't worry. I will find a way to liberate Orpheus.

Voss_83.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_83.text: I did not come this far for you to turn your back on the First Mother's son.

Voss_120.speaker: Lae'zel
Voss_120.text: Gith'ka tavkim krash'ht. You put your trust in me, Voss. I plan to honour it.
Voss_120.context: NodeContext: Gith's light guides us. GITH-kah TAHV-kim krasht. (With a bit of guttural edge.)

Voss_51.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_51.text: Yes. And it seems I have no choice but to trust. There is but one Prism, and you are its key.

Voss_73.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_73.text: And yet it seems I have no choice but to trust. There is but one Prism, and you are its key.

Voss_122.speaker: Player
Voss_122.text: It's not my cost to pay. Figure it out yourself.

Voss_135.speaker: Lae'zel
Voss_135.text: What are you playing at? I will find a way yet to free the prince. This was my promise!

Voss_128.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_128.text: I thought you'd freed yourself from the lich queen's dead claws. How wrong I was.

Voss_16.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_16.text: Yet your companion disagrees, Lae'zel. What am I to make of that?

Voss_111.speaker: Player
Voss_111.text: Raphael wants a powerful crown in trade. Who knows what chaos he might sow?

Voss_30.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_30.text: No more than Vlaakith will sow in Tu'narath and beyond. No more than the ghaik will sow across every plane.

Voss_76.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_76.text: There is nothing I won't do, nothing I won't give, to free Orpheus from the Prism. The marks I bear are proof enough of that.

Voss_130.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_130.text: But you - you are the one who carries the Astral Prism. You are the one who must free the prince.

Voss_117.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_117.text: That Hammer is the only thing capable of smashing the chains that bind the Prince of the Comet.

Voss_40.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_40.text: Find a way to retrieve the Hammer and free Orpheus from the Prism.

Voss_6.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_6.text: I will assemble his remaining honour guard and plan our next actions.

Voss_113.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_113.text: Together, we will yet free The True Heir of Gith's blessed Empire.

Voss_123.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_123.text: He will free us from Vlaakith, and lead our kith'raki against the ghaik.

Voss_103.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_103.text: Istik - I will wait in the underground. Seek me when you have the Hammer in hand.

Voss_118.speaker: Player
Voss_118.text: Any idea where Raphael might keep the Orphic Hammer?

Voss_132.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_132.text: A devil of Raphael's stature does not simply make camp on the shores of the Styx.

Voss_28.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_28.text: He will have made a sanctuary for himself. A lavish one, too, one that caters to his many vices.

Voss_92.speaker: Lae'zel
Voss_92.text: The House of Hope. We must find a way in.

Voss_41.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_41.text: The House of Hope, you say? I couldn't ask for a name more fitting.

Voss_67.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_67.text: Every house has an entrance, istik - even those in the Hells. You must find it.

Voss_121.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_121.text: He must keep the Orphic Hammer there.

Voss_19.speaker: Player
Voss_19.text: I'd sooner just kill you instead.

Voss_139.text: You are wasting your time and mine. Our true enemy is the elder brain. Focus your mind there.

Voss_108.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_108.text: Raphael possesses a powerful relic called the Orphic Hammer.

Voss_131.speaker: Player
Voss_131.text: It's over, Voss. I'm here for your head.

Voss_45.speaker: Player
Voss_45.text: Raphael did not offer any bargain.

Voss_88.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_88.text: Do you take me for a fool? The devil may speak in poetry, but his purpose was crystal clear.

Voss_105.speaker: Player
Voss_105.text: I'm not interested in pacting with devils, Voss.

Voss_42.speaker: Player
Voss_42.text: No. I will find another way to liberate Orpheus.

Voss_3.speaker: Player
Voss_3.text: I'm here for one reason, Voss: to kill you.

Voss_61.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_61.text: Lae'zel of K'liir. Warrior of warriors.

Voss_64.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_64.text: Tell me you took the devil's deal. Tell me you will free Gith's heir.

Voss_15.speaker: Player
Voss_15.text: I changed my mind. I hold the Hammer that will free Orpheus from his chains.

Voss_93.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
Voss_93.text: Be still and be silent. I'm here for Raphael.

AD_RaphaelVoss_3.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
AD_RaphaelVoss_3.text: You must want for something, need something.

AD_RaphaelVoss_1.speaker: Raphael
AD_RaphaelVoss_1.text: Everyone does, but what I need, you do not have, and never will.

AD_RaphaelVoss_5.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
AD_RaphaelVoss_5.text: You underestimate the Forgotten Prince's closest sword, devil.

AD_RaphaelVoss_6.speaker: Raphael
AD_RaphaelVoss_6.text: If you had any bargaining chips, they've all rather floated off into the Astral Plane. You're out of luck.

AD_RaphaelVoss_4.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
AD_RaphaelVoss_4.text: I will pay any toll, serve any foul whim. Name the price.

AD_RaphaelVoss_2.speaker: Raphael
AD_RaphaelVoss_2.text: Is there anything duller than a loyal dog? I much prefer a cat. Meow.

AD_RaphaelVoss_8.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
AD_RaphaelVoss_8.text: Hand it over. Much more than your fate and mine rests on it.

AD_RaphaelVoss_0.speaker: Raphael
AD_RaphaelVoss_0.text: Even if you had it, what in the Nine Hells would you do with it? Think a little, Captain Voss.

AD_RaphaelVoss_7.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
AD_RaphaelVoss_7.text: He can be set free. I know he can be set free.

AD_RaphaelRetreats_0.text: Enough! The deal is off the table.
AD_RaphaelRetreats_0.context: NodeContext: Annoyed - player just attacked him repeatedly. It didn't hurt, but he's annoyed, and vanishes from sight after speaking

Emperor_AfterRaphael_115.text: Something was blocking me from hearing your thoughts.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_80.text: It's concerning that something could come between us like that, especially when we are so close to the elder brain.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_119.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_119.text: I'm just glad to have you back.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_116.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_116.text: It was nice to have a moment of peace and quiet.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_106.text: I can understand that - there's reprieve in solitude.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_23.text: But it's concerning that something could intervene like that, especially when we are so close to the elder brain.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_61.text: Do you have any idea what it was?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_57.text: Raphael? Well - thank you for your honesty.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_78.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_78.text: It was the elder brain - it was trying to take hold of me.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_96.text: Then the situation is worse than I thought.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_77.text: If it read your thoughts, it knows exactly what your intentions are. And it is already plotting counter-moves to stop you.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_15.text: We must press on. I will bolster your mental defences. Let us hope that allows us to regain some of our lost advantage before it finds you.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_43.text: You're trying to deceive me. But why?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_82.text: Someone must have intervened. Someone you don't want me to know about.
Emperor_AfterRaphael_82.context: NodeContext: like a detective pacing around a room reasoning to themself aloud

Emperor_AfterRaphael_37.speaker: Narrator
Emperor_AfterRaphael_37.text: *You feel the touch of the Emperor's mind peeling at the edge of yours, trying to gain access, and succeeding.*

Emperor_AfterRaphael_105.context: NodeContext: stumbling on the correct answer

Emperor_AfterRaphael_53.text: Of course. I should have known the devil would come sniffing.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_26.text: The stench of impending chaos is irresistible to them.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_124.text: And what did he want with you?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_79.text: What were the terms of this deal?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_135.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_135.text: He offered me the means to free Orpheus in exchange for the Crown on top of the brain.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_88.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_88.text: He knows how to free Orpheus.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_38.text: How interesting. No doubt he impressed upon you the need to do so.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_126.text: And what did he want in return for this knowledge?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_4.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_4.text: The Crown that the brain is wearing.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_65.text: Tell me you turned him down?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_87.text: Tell me you turned him down.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_10.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_10.text: It was a good deal, all right?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_93.text: I was absent for one moment...
Emperor_AfterRaphael_93.context: NodeContext: vocal equivalent of a facepalm

Emperor_AfterRaphael_130.text: If there is one thing you can be certain of, it is that the devil will come to collect.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_140.text: But that is your problem. I will not let you put our survival at risk. I have Orpheus well under control. Stay away from him.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_129.text: Now come - we have an elder brain to destroy.
Emperor_AfterRaphael_129.context: NodeContext: like an adult making the boundaries clear to a child, and then rediverting their attention back to the main issue

Emperor_AfterRaphael_49.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_49.text: It was a good deal. I accepted.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_0.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_0.text: I don't see how that's any of your business.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_42.speaker: Narrator
Emperor_AfterRaphael_42.text: *You feel the touch of the Emperor's mind peeling at the edge of yours, trying to gain access.*

Emperor_AfterRaphael_131.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_131.text: Open your mind to it. You have nothing to hide.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_48.speaker: Narrator
Emperor_AfterRaphael_48.text: *Its thoughts slide into yours, turning through them like fingers, sifting for answers... which it finds.*

Emperor_AfterRaphael_89.text: Good. I'm glad. But be careful.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_20.text: Then we must be very careful.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_21.text: The devil is like a cockroach - no matter what you do to it, it will always come back.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_109.text: I doubt this will be the last time you are approached.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_59.text: I trust that you will continue to remember who is really on your side.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_137.text: Without my protection, you cannot defeat the elder brain. You cannot even get close to it. No matter what the devil whispers in your ear.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_97.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_97.text: You're the one who's always talking about trust. If you trust me, you'll stop this right now.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_33.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_33.text: Here's an idea - you stay out of my head and I'll stay out of yours.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_41.speaker: Narrator
Emperor_AfterRaphael_41.text: *You feel its presence withdrawing from the fringes of your awareness.*

Emperor_AfterRaphael_55.text: I shall respect your privacy on this occasion.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_122.text: But know that if you have jeopardised our mutual project, I will be forced to reconsider our alliance.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_103.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_103.text: Get out of my head or I'll throw the Astral Prism into the Hells.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_72.text: And risk becoming enthralled to the elder brain?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_63.context: CinematicNodeContext: A beat. Player narrows their eyes angrily - they WOULD dare.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_91.speaker: Narrator
Emperor_AfterRaphael_91.text: *Again - the Emperor pries at the boundaries of your thoughts, invasive, curious.*

Emperor_AfterRaphael_6.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_6.text: Does it matter? I said no.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_71.text: I'm glad you had the sense to turn him down. But it certainly does matter.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_5.text: Anything that threatens our alliance, threatens our chances of defeating the elder brain.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_36.text: So I ask again - what were the terms of the deal he offered you?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_102.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_102.text: He wanted the Crown the brain is wearing, and offered me the means to free Orpheus.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_32.text: Just imagine - a crown of sufficient power to dominate an elder brain atop a devil's head. You would be trading one apocalyptic event for another.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_76.text: Thank you for telling me. And for rejecting him.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_101.text: And now we must be doubly on our guard.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_136.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_136.text: I don't know, I didn't wait to find out.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_8.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_8.text: That's between me and the devil.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_46.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_46.text: Does it matter? I turned down his offer.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_86.speaker: Player
Emperor_AfterRaphael_86.text: He wants the Crown that's on the brain.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_47.text: Giving a devil what he wants sounds like a brilliant idea.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_104.text: And what did he offer you in return for bringing it to him?

Emperor_AfterRaphael_45.text: Then perhaps my protection - but I was sure... never mind.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_56.text: We must press on. I will bolster your mental defences and make sure this doesn't happen again.

Emperor_AfterRaphael_113.text: You play the fool, and you play it poorly. You know something.

ThreeWay_VossScene_12.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
ThreeWay_VossScene_12.text: You must hear me, devil. I will do whatever it takes - give you anything you ask.

ThreeWay_VossScene_3.speaker: Raphael
ThreeWay_VossScene_3.text: There is only one thing in this world that I desire. You do not have it, and you never will.

ThreeWay_VossScene_11.speaker: Lae'zel
ThreeWay_VossScene_11.text: The kith'rak? What deal would he make with this devil?

ThreeWay_VossScene_7.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
ThreeWay_VossScene_7.text: You must help me, Raphael. For the sake of my people.

ThreeWay_VossScene_5.speaker: Raphael
ThreeWay_VossScene_5.text: Hush now, Voss. These guests may not know it yet, but they want the same thing that you do.

ThreeWay_VossScene_1.speaker: Raphael
ThreeWay_VossScene_1.text: And unlike you, they have something of value to offer in return.

ThreeWay_VossScene_6.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
ThreeWay_VossScene_6.text: Lae'zel, T'lak'ma Ghir - the devil holds the key to freeing the gith people. Right here, right now, you could seal our fate.

ThreeWay_VossScene_2.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
ThreeWay_VossScene_2.text: Whatever you discuss with this devil, I must hear of it. Find me below in the taproom once you're loosed from his claws.

ThreeWay_VossScene_0.context: CinematicNodeContext: Raphael waves his hand, dismissing Voss, who leaves the room off-camera.

ThreeWay_VossScene_10.speaker: Kith'rak Voss
ThreeWay_VossScene_10.text: Lae'zel, T'lak'ma Ghir - the devil holds the key to freeing the gith people. Right here, right now, you could seal our fate.

PAD_MessengerReaction_0.speaker: Player
PAD_MessengerReaction_0.text: What has he put in my pockets?! I felt something there.

AD_MessengerGreets_0.speaker: 1029999e-41d0-4f10-88c1-fa2f5718a609
AD_MessengerGreets_0.text: You're here in one piece. We knew you would make it. My employer has an invitation you won't want to turn down.

AD_RaphaelAttacked_0.text: Like a mosquito nibbling at a dragon. Begone.
AD_RaphaelAttacked_0.context: NodeContext: amused - player just attacked him and he didn't feel a thing

AD_RaphaelAttacked_1.text: I'm running out of patience. Desist.
AD_RaphaelAttacked_1.context: NodeContext: annoyed, but not raising your voice

Raphael_1.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_1.text: My favourite future clients. Are you ready to accept my kind offer?

Raphael_35.speaker: Karlach
Raphael_35.context: NodeContext: Fear and worry in her voice. Player has just said they want to sign a contract with Raphael

Raphael_28.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_28.text: Excellent, excellent. You'll find everything is in order.
Raphael_28.context: CinematicNodeContext: Raphael gestures to his left, and a floating contract appears in a burst of flame, hovering

Raphael_23.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_23.text: My dear Karlach, I'm delighted you've seen sense. You'll find everything is in order.
Raphael_23.context: CinematicNodeContext: Raphael gestures to his left, and a floating contract appears in a burst of flame, hovering

Raphael_29.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_29.text: And this agreement will bring us both what we want. You'll save your world, I'll unite the hells. And the illithids will be eradicated.

Raphael_33.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_33.text: A pleasure doing business with you.

Raphael_32.speaker: Player
Raphael_32.text: How do I use the Hammer to free Orpheus?

Raphael_6.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_6.text: Before the end comes, you'll find yourself in his presence again. When that happens, use the Hammer to shatter the chains that hold him.

Raphael_27.speaker: Player
Raphael_27.text: If you weren't my last fucking option, I'd rip your horns off.

Raphael_25.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_25.text: Ah, what fun we would've had if you'd tried.

Raphael_17.speaker: Player
Raphael_17.text: Thanks, Raphael. You just helped to save Baldur's Gate.

Raphael_5.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_5.text: But of course. I could never allow such a festering pustule of a city to die - it's an object lesson in mortal excess.

Raphael_36.speaker: Player
Raphael_36.text: I still expect this to end badly.

Raphael_21.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_21.text: Everything that ends, ends badly. You just bought a chance to ward off the ending for a little longer.

Raphael_20.speaker: Player
Raphael_20.text: The pleasure's all mine - I got everything I wanted out of this.

Raphael_0.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_0.text: You certainly came out on top, didn't you? But I'm more than happy to take a slight loss on this particular transaction. I like you.

Raphael_22.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_22.text: You will find yourself in Orpheus' presence before the end comes. When the moment comes, use the Hammer to shatter the chains that hold him.

Raphael_26.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_26.text: Be sure to keep the Hammer safe until then. Your survival depends on it.

Raphael_19.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_19.text: And our deal depends on your contract. I'll keep it safe for you, in my House of Hope.

Raphael_10.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_10.text: Now - I have business elsewhere. But rest assured, we'll talk again.

Raphael_16.speaker: Gale
Raphael_16.text: That was reckless. In a devil's hands, the crown could be as dangerous as any artefact in existence - we need to nullify the terms of that deal.
Raphael_16.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, you didn't listen to him

Raphael_31.speaker: Gale
Raphael_31.text: To do that, we'll need to find a diabolist willing to open a backdoor to the hells, sneak into Raphael's home, and destroy the contract. Simple.
Raphael_31.context: NodeContext: annoyed that all of this is necessary because of a bad choice the player made. Outlining an impossible plan and finishing on that very sarcastic 'simple'.

Raphael_18.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_18.text: *The ink has barely dried, yet you feel a growing disquiet at what exactly you just signed. Perhaps a diabolist can offer some comfort. Or a way out... for a devil's bargain is a hard one to break.*

Raphael_24.speaker: Player
Raphael_24.text: Remind me of the terms of the deal.

Raphael_34.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_34.text: I give you the Orphic Hammer, the means by which Prince Orpheus of the githyanki can be freed from his chains.

Raphael_30.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_30.text: You give me the Crown once you have destroyed the elder brain.

Raphael_12.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_12.text: Still holding out hope for another solution?

Raphael_9.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_9.text: Destiny waits in the wings. Find the brain, destroy it, and seize that Crown.

Warlock_17.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_17.text: Go see Raphael - then I might let you buy me a drink.

Warlock_30.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_30.text: Damn, Hoots. That new batch burns stronger than a pit fiend's fist.
Warlock_30.context: NodeContext: talking to the bartender, impressed by the strength of the drink she has just finished (no need to show her drinking it)

Warlock_51.speaker: Hoots Hooligan
Warlock_51.text: I'll take that as a compliment.
Warlock_51.context: NodeContext: smiling, referring to somebody reacting strongly to a drink you just poured them

Warlock_111.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_111.text: Take it however you want, but I'll be having my usual from now on.
Warlock_111.context: NodeContext: talking to a bartender, just drank a particularly powerful shot and you're impressed but will NOT be drinking it again

Warlock_173.speaker: Karlach
Warlock_173.context: NodeContext: Talking about Korilla, servant of Raphael.

Warlock_142.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_142.text: Oh! Raphael's latest client - saviour of the city, he says!
Warlock_142.context: CinematicNodeContext: turns to playerNodeContext: delighted

Warlock_45.speaker: Player
Warlock_45.text: I'm not Raphael's client. He's my pawn.

Warlock_22.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_22.text: Whatever you need to tell yourself, honey. Deep down you know the truth. And so do I.

Warlock_117.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_117.text: You've made his century, you know. You're going to save us, Baldur's Gate - everyone, he says.

Warlock_177.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_177.text: Indeed we do. Seems like an age ago that the boss sent me to keep an eye on you.

Warlock_181.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_181.text: And I must have done a damn fine job because here you are - safe, sound, and already signed up to team Raphael.

Warlock_59.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_59.text: When I'm not keeping my eye on potential clients like you, I make sure the House of Hope is fully secure.

Warlock_149.speaker: Player
Warlock_149.text: Surely Raphael can defend his own house.

Warlock_39.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_39.text: When he's there, yes. But he's a busy man - contracts and interests in many places, and on many planes.

Warlock_141.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_141.text: This current crisis has him so busy he's barely been home since he met you.

Warlock_160.speaker: Player
Warlock_160.text: Who would be stupid enough to break into a devil's home?

Warlock_63.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_63.text: Devils often have prettier hoards than dragons. Sneaking thieves into their vaults is a lucrative business - doesn't usually end well for the thieves.
Warlock_63.context: NodeContext: cheerful, but the last phrase has a trace of annoyance. She doesn't like these 'thieves'

Warlock_87.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_87.text: But sometimes the thieves are rich, smart, or well-connected enough to come back in one piece. Take our esteemed Lord Gortash, for example.
Warlock_87.context: NodeContext: not dropping her cheerful persona, but with some real venom for Lord Gortash. She really doesn't like him

Warlock_151.speaker: Narrator
Warlock_151.text: *She's enjoying your company and the liquor has loosened her tongue, but she's anxious about the direction the conversation's taking.*

Warlock_10.speaker: Player
Warlock_10.text: Have you ever been tempted to earn some extra coin selling infernal secrets?

Warlock_62.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_62.context: NodeContext: surprised by an accusation of treachery

Warlock_182.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_182.text: I'll take Raphael's secrets to the grave.

Warlock_66.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_66.text: If that prick Gortash came nosing around my turf, I'd tell him to stick his gauntlet where the sun don't shine.

Warlock_150.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_150.text: But somebody helped him out. Some diabolist with a loose sense of duty, and a hunger to be richer than Mammon.
Warlock_150.context: NodeContext: Bitterly. She is all about duty. 'Mammon' is an archdevil.

Warlock_105.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_105.text: Conversation's over. I've got to sober up and get back to work.
Warlock_105.context: NodeContext: stern warning - she's telling us to shut up

Warlock_21.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_21.text: I'm insulted you'd even suggest that.

Warlock_35.speaker: Player
Warlock_35.text: Gortash must have had help from someone with infernal connections. Any idea who?

Warlock_83.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_83.text: Yeah - a diabolist with a loose sense of duty, and a hunger to be richer than Mammon.
Warlock_83.context: NodeContext: Bitterly. She is all about duty. 'Mammon' is an archdevil.

Warlock_108.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_108.text: I almost wish he'd asked me. I'd have told him to stick his gauntlet where the sun don't shine, and wiped that smug little grin off his face.

Warlock_6.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_6.text: Same kind of people who'd ask about it. Folks with a death wish.
Warlock_6.context: NodeContext: stern warning - she's telling us to shut up

Warlock_15.speaker: Player
Warlock_15.text: Enough of this - enjoy your drink, and think of lighter things.

Warlock_183.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_183.text: It's hard to find any light in this bloody city.

Warlock_101.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_101.text: I can't wait to get back to the hells - at least it's warm there. The wind off the harbour here cuts me to the bone.
Warlock_101.context: NodeContext: she's sincere about this, despite how ludicrous it might sound

Warlock_40.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_40.text: I hope things turn out well for you, I really do. Cheers.
Warlock_40.context: NodeContext: sadly - she knows (but we don't) that things won't turn out well at all

Warlock_184.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_184.text: Talking about this won't end well for either of us, so if you'll excuse me -
Warlock_184.context: NodeContext: abruptly cutting off a conversatoin that's leading toward controversial topics

Warlock_12.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_12.text: As a noose. Doesn't stop people from testing it, though.
Warlock_12.context: NodeContext: 'As a noose' is a response to 'security must be tight'. Proudly. She helps out with that security

Warlock_170.speaker: Player
Warlock_170.text: You're very enthusiastic - you really like working for Raphael?

Warlock_46.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_46.text: More than anything. My old dwarven master used to beat me and feed me scraps - Raphael treats me right and feeds me well.
Warlock_46.context: NodeContext: cheerful - explaining why she likes working for a devil

Warlock_27.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_27.text: Better to feast in the Hells than go begging in the Heavens.

Warlock_153.speaker: Player
Warlock_153.text: I hope you're right about saving the city.

Warlock_148.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_148.text: The boss is always right. Even though he's so very wrong.
Warlock_148.context: NodeContext: mischevious - emphasis on 'wrong' is her cheeky acknowledgement that 'the boss' is a devil

Warlock_24.speaker: Player
Warlock_24.text: I think I made a bad choice.

Warlock_4.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_4.text: Don't worry - the boss treats his clients right. He's as honest as his life is long.

Warlock_69.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_69.text: Oh! You must have slipped by me earlier. Raphael's very disappointed you turned him down.
Warlock_69.context: CinematicNodeContext: turns to playerNodeContext: disappointed, but encouraging

Warlock_115.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_115.text: He's gutted you know - had such high hopes for you.

Warlock_166.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_166.text: Laugh all you want, dynamite. You're not coming out of this alive without him. Then again, you probably won't come out alive at all.

Warlock_171.speaker: Player
Warlock_171.text: He better get used to disappointment - I'm not making any deal with him.

Warlock_174.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_174.text: You won't come out of this alive without him.

Warlock_93.speaker: Player
Warlock_93.text: Did he tell you to try and win me over with your charms?

Warlock_169.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_169.text: Cheeky. We might be in a brothel, but I'm not that kind of gal. You should reconsider, though.

Warlock_48.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_48.text: He knows me - and you - better than that. You should reconsider his offer.

Warlock_94.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_94.text: The boss might be a devil, but he'll treat you more honestly than anyone else in the city.

Warlock_104.speaker: Player
Warlock_104.text: What exactly is it you do for him?

Warlock_176.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_176.text: Plenty. But right now, I have one job - you.

Warlock_152.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_152.text: I'm talking to you openly - mortal to mortal - and I'm begging you to sign the contract.

Warlock_167.speaker: Player
Warlock_167.text: I doubt that - there are plenty of good people here.

Warlock_73.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_73.text: I'm sure you're right. Between the dictators, the murderers, the Guild, and the cult, the city's brimming with goodness.

Warlock_113.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_113.text: I am. You can save yourself and the city if you sign that contract.

Warlock_41.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_41.text: Listen - because I'll only say this once - this fight isn't just about Baldur's Gate, or the Sword Coast, or even Faerûn.

Warlock_180.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_180.text: If the brain wins, the Illithid Empire returns, and worlds you've never even dreamed of will die.
Warlock_180.context: NodeContext: insistent, emphasising the scale of the horror

Warlock_80.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_80.text: Raphael can stop it - he wants to - and he knows how. You're the key. You always have been.

Warlock_76.speaker: Player
Warlock_76.text: Maybe I rejected him too hastily.

Warlock_131.speaker: Karlach
Warlock_131.context: NodeContext: Piping up when the player says 'Maybe I rejected Raphael too easily'

Warlock_172.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_172.text: You did. But that's fine - there's still time.

Warlock_136.speaker: Player
Warlock_136.text: Then why make demands of me instead of just helping?

Warlock_65.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_65.text: He's a devil. It's his nature. He needs to get his due.
Warlock_65.context: CinematicNodeContext: with a shrugNodeContext: matter of fact

Warlock_128.speaker: Player
Warlock_128.text: I'll stop the brain without his help.

Warlock_109.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_109.text: I doubt it - but even if you do, you won't survive the fight.
Warlock_109.context: NodeContext: with a hint of sadness

Warlock_110.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_110.text: I'd reconsider if I were you.

Warlock_154.speaker: Player
Warlock_154.text: I don't believe a devil cares about the fate of the world.

Warlock_7.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_7.text: I won't pretend he's an altruist. But he's looked at the balance sheet - no world, no souls.

Warlock_114.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_114.text: And it's hard to get leverage on an illithid - they make terrible clients.
Warlock_114.context: NodeContext: with a smile, trying to make light of a serious situation

Warlock_157.speaker: Player
Warlock_157.text: I'm not convinced - I'll stop the brain without his help.

Warlock_175.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_175.text: Nothing wrong with that. I hope you make the right choice.
Warlock_175.context: NodeContext: with a shrug, sincere in her hope

Warlock_102.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_102.context: CinematicNodeContext: turns to playerNodeContext: cheerful

Warlock_52.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_52.text: You've put me out of pocket, you know. Raphael bet me five soul coins you'd reach the city in one piece.

Warlock_50.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_50.text: Good to see you again, even if you have put me out of pocket. The boss bet me five soul coins you'd reach the city in one piece.
Warlock_50.context: NodeContext: cheerful - she bet against us surviving in a 'playful' wager, but is glad to see us nonetheless

Warlock_53.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_53.text: He rented a room upstairs in the hope that you'd drop by.

Warlock_125.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_125.text: Ah, I forget we've never met. I've had my eyes and ears on you so long, we feel like old friends.

Warlock_70.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_70.text: Korrilla is my name. I'm Raphael's... assistant, shall we say.

Warlock_16.speaker: Player
Warlock_16.text: No interest in meeting up with devil scum.

Warlock_72.speaker: Player
Warlock_72.text: I'll go see him - we have unfinished business.

Warlock_14.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_14.text: Yes, you do - and what better place to do business than in the home of the oldest trade?
Warlock_14.context: NodeContext: cheerful - 'the oldest trade' is a reference to the brothel she's drinking in

Warlock_78.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_78.text: Take your time - have a drink, sample the goods. Go see him when you're feeling refreshed.

Warlock_89.speaker: Player
Warlock_89.text: What does he want with me?

Warlock_82.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_82.text: He wants to help you save the world. What else?
Warlock_82.context: NodeContext: as if it's the most obvious thing in the world

Warlock_20.speaker: Player
Warlock_20.text: He should have stayed home - I have no intention of speaking with him.

Warlock_146.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_146.text: Such a shame - you won't survive without his help, and I'll miss your pretty face.

Warlock_133.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_133.text: At least hear him out - you'll be surprised by what he has to offer.

Warlock_54.speaker: Karlach
Warlock_54.text: Something's off about this one. On your guard.

Warlock_44.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_44.text: A toast to Raphael's latest client, the saviour of the city.

Warlock_3.speaker: Player
Warlock_3.text: I'm already starting to regret making that deal with him.

Warlock_47.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_47.text: I'm not for sale. My time's not for sale. My affection's not for sale. I'm here on other business.
Warlock_47.context: CinematicNodeContext: hasn't looked up from her mug yet - is muttering darkly, she's clearly said this to a lot of people who've assumed she's a prostitute (she's standing at the bar in a brothel)

Warlock_64.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_64.text: We'll celebrate together in the House of Hope when the victory's won.

Warlock_97.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_97.text: C'mere - I'm not going to start an argument. I just want to know why you turned the boss down.

Warlock_100.speaker: Player
Warlock_100.text: Hah, are you joking? Because I hate him.

Warlock_38.speaker: Player
Warlock_38.text: Doesn't matter why. My word is final - no deal.

Warlock_143.speaker: Player
Warlock_143.text: Did he tell you to try and win me over with your charms?

Warlock_122.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_122.text: Seen sense yet? Raphael's still waiting. He can still help you get through this.

Warlock_129.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_129.text: There you are. I'd almost lost track of you. Almost.

Warlock_23.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_23.text: Speaking of Raphael - did you miss his invitation? He's waiting for you in Sharess' Caress.

Warlock_13.speaker: Player
Warlock_13.text: You know, I think I did miss Raphael.

Warlock_81.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_81.text: Then go un-miss him. And hurry up. Devils are patient by nature, but even Raphael has certain limitations.

Warlock_134.speaker: Player
Warlock_134.text: What does he want with me?

Warlock_75.speaker: Player
Warlock_75.text: He should have stayed home - I have no intention of speaking with him.

Warlock_58.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_58.text: He'll be in Sharess' Caress in Wyrm's Crossing. Go, now, if you know what's good for you - and the world.

Warlock_159.speaker: Korrilla
Warlock_159.text: If it isn't Raphael's latest client - saviour of the city, isn't it?

AD_WarlockAfterRaphael_0.speaker: Korrilla
AD_WarlockAfterRaphael_0.text: Hey! You paid Raphael a visit? I want to hear all about it.
AD_WarlockAfterRaphael_0.context: NodeContext: calling out across a busy bar, so raised voice on 'hey', but then warm and inviting

Raphael_SoloScene_8.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_8.text: *A crackle at the edge of your consciousness... the Emperor has been silenced once more.*

Raphael_SoloScene_90.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_90.text: Here we are again. Have you reconsidered? Would you like to hear what I'm offering?

Raphael_SoloScene_211.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_211.text: What do you have that I could possibly want?

Raphael_SoloScene_174.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_174.text: I'm glad you came. Not to my door, not yet, but to the final reckoning.
Raphael_SoloScene_174.context: NodeContext: With a smile - genuinely pleased to be coming to the final stage of his business with the players

Raphael_SoloScene_252.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_252.text: I trust you'll be on better behaviour than when we last met. There's precious little time remaining for your mischief.

Raphael_SoloScene_192.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_192.text: One more thing before we begin, though.

Raphael_SoloScene_137.context: CinematicNodeContext: Raphael clicks his fingers, and the lights in the room dim for a moment. He smiles.

Raphael_SoloScene_24.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_24.text: *For the first time since the nautiloid, your mind is clear. It's... unsettling.*

Raphael_SoloScene_233.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_233.text: Did you just cure me of the tadpole? With a click of your fingers?

Raphael_SoloScene_12.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_12.text: Wouldn't that be exquisite? But no.

Raphael_SoloScene_255.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_255.text: I'm afraid the tadpole is still there. But I did shut out your other visitor for a while, so we can enjoy some privacy.

Raphael_SoloScene_190.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_190.context: NodeContext: pleased with himself - he just did something we thought impossible

Raphael_SoloScene_223.speaker: Karlach
Raphael_SoloScene_223.context: NodeContext: Reracting to Raphael stopping the Emperor (illithid tadpole guy) from talking to us. Suspicious but curious/ maybe even a little impressed.

Raphael_SoloScene_72.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_72.text: I'd take a mind flayer over a devil any day.

Raphael_SoloScene_260.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_260.text: I trust the illithid more than I trust you.

Raphael_SoloScene_140.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_140.text: Then speak freely - tell me why you brought me here.

Raphael_SoloScene_97.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_97.text: I brought you here because I'm true to my word, and I can make all of this tadpole business go away.

Raphael_SoloScene_117.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_117.text: Which means you and your lovely friends can remain blessedly free of tentacles.

Raphael_SoloScene_197.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_197.text: Unless some have already sprouted in places I can't see.

Raphael_SoloScene_118.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_118.text: I'll admit - you've impressed me. I wasn't sure you'd make it this far.

Raphael_SoloScene_214.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_214.text: But no matter how far you come, you're still on the road to ruin - a road that leads directly to a confrontation with the elder brain.
Raphael_SoloScene_214.context: NodeContext: laying out the facts - he wants us to understand the gravity of the situation

Raphael_SoloScene_154.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_154.text: At best, it will kill you and everyone else in this city. At worst, it will assimilate you, and you won't have enough free will left to even wish you were dead.
Raphael_SoloScene_154.context: NodeContext: laying out the facts - he wants us to understand the gravity of the situation

Raphael_SoloScene_50.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_50.text: You have the key to destroying it in the palm of your hand, though.
Raphael_SoloScene_50.context: NodeContext: open - he's trying to win us over

Raphael_SoloScene_199.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_199.text: No, Gale. Mystra might have you believe martyrdom is the only solution. I offer you a way to survive.

Raphael_SoloScene_248.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_248.text: In a manner of speaking. But it's the one inside the Prism that you need. Not the illithid - the gith.

Raphael_SoloScene_144.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_144.text: No, no, no. It has only helped to push you toward your own destruction. It wants you to be an illithid, the very thing you have sought to avoid.
Raphael_SoloScene_144.context: NodeContext: slightly irritated - but only slightly.  as if speaking to a stupid child

Raphael_SoloScene_23.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_23.text: It is the illithid's prisoner that can save you. The gith.

Raphael_SoloScene_68.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_68.text: I can give you the means to break him free.
Raphael_SoloScene_68.context: NodeContext: making a grand offer - this is big news delivered solemnly

Raphael_SoloScene_224.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_224.text: The Orphic Hammer. An artefact capable of shattering the chains that hold Prince Orpheus is held securely in my House of Hope even now.

Raphael_SoloScene_88.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_88.text: Then you will hand it over. Orpheus must be set free.

Raphael_SoloScene_45.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_45.text: Surely you realise, there is an exchange to be made. You scratch my back, I scratch your parasite.
Raphael_SoloScene_45.context: NodeContext: second 'scratch' as in erase. A ltitle bit of wordplay

Raphael_SoloScene_253.speaker: Karlach
Raphael_SoloScene_253.context: NodeContext: Raphael's proposing a 'trade', so Karlach is like... of course he is.

Raphael_SoloScene_196.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_196.text: Wouldn't expect more. So what do you want?

Raphael_SoloScene_168.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_168.text: What are you hoping to get out of all this?

Raphael_SoloScene_221.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_221.text: Power. You free Orpheus, and in doing so, save the city, the Sword Coast, perhaps the whole world... and your own precious skin, too.
Raphael_SoloScene_221.context: NodeContext: He's speaking to us almost as equals here. Being very honest about what he wants - 'power'. No more lies. Just the plain facts.

Raphael_SoloScene_111.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_111.text: And you give me the Crown that dominates the elder brain.
Raphael_SoloScene_111.context: NodeContext: this is the crux of his offer - he says it with the boldness of somebody used to getting what he wants.

Raphael_SoloScene_237.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_237.text: I suppose you want my soul in exchange for the Hammer?

Raphael_SoloScene_92.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_92.text: You really do think highly of yourself. My sights are set on something much more valuable than your soul, succulent though it would be.

Raphael_SoloScene_26.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_26.text: I want the Crown that dominates the elder brain.
Raphael_SoloScene_26.context: NodeContext: this is the crux of his offer - he says it with the boldness of somebody used to getting what he wants.

Raphael_SoloScene_251.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_251.text: And you, Lae'zel of K'liir, want to free the forgotten prince, do you not?

Raphael_SoloScene_131.speaker: Lae'zel
Raphael_SoloScene_131.text: I don't want to free him. I want to kill him.

Raphael_SoloScene_14.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_14.text: Lae'zel of K'liir - do you think you can take a blade to the prince while the illithid still binds him?

Raphael_SoloScene_220.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_220.text: Goodness, no. If you wish Gith's long-suffering son dead, you need the Hammer.

Raphael_SoloScene_186.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_186.text: Then it is settled, is it not? A Crown for a Hammer. A bargain of a lifetime, Lae'zel of K'liir.

Raphael_SoloScene_155.speaker: Gale
Raphael_SoloScene_155.text: The Crown of Karsus cannot be handed over to this devil.  Agree to nothing.

Raphael_SoloScene_55.speaker: Gale
Raphael_SoloScene_55.text: Handing that crown to this devil would be like feeding gunpowder to a lava worm. Agree to nothing.

Raphael_SoloScene_230.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_230.text: *This is your chance to free Gith's only son - but Raphael might wreak untold havok with this Crown.*

Raphael_SoloScene_122.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_122.text: *But perhaps there is another way to take the Hammer, a way into the seat of Raphael's operations - the House of Hope.*

Raphael_SoloScene_61.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_61.text: I'm tempted - but tell me why you're so eager to get hold of the crown?

Raphael_SoloScene_182.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_182.text: Power. Ancient and full of wonder.

Raphael_SoloScene_84.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_84.text: I have craved it ever since the archwizard Karsus created it, long centuries ago, and brought doom to the empire of Netheril.
Raphael_SoloScene_84.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past - moving into storytelling mode as he begins a monologue that continues for several lines

Raphael_SoloScene_67.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_67.text: That was the great age of humanity, and Netheril's flying sky-cities were the apex of civilisation.

Raphael_SoloScene_70.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_70.text: I was there the day it all fell apart. Entire cities plummeted from the sky, like angels with broken wings.
Raphael_SoloScene_70.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past

Raphael_SoloScene_19.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_19.text: The screams, oh the screams - hundreds of thousands of people watching in horror as the ground came up to meet them. It was not a happy meeting.
Raphael_SoloScene_19.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past - last phrase with a smile. He finds this funny.

Raphael_SoloScene_242.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_242.text: And Karsus was responsible. Not driven by malice, but by ambition. He forged a Crown imbued with all the powers of magic, a Crown that would make any who wore it a god.

Raphael_SoloScene_82.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_82.text: Men cannot contain so much power. The Crown destroyed its creator, and his empire fell with him.

Raphael_SoloScene_47.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_47.text: *Could this be the crown worn by the elder brain? The word of a devil counts for little, but perhaps you might find more reliable proof on the arcane bookshelves of Sorcerous Sundries...*

Raphael_SoloScene_77.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_77.text: Karsus' Folly, the bards and scholars call it. I call it hope. The hope of creating a better world, and the perils of unchecked hubris.
Raphael_SoloScene_77.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past

Raphael_SoloScene_79.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_79.text: I knew then that the folly of mortals could be the triumph of devils, and that I could use that Crown to unite the Nine under one Archdevil Supreme. Me.
Raphael_SoloScene_79.context: NodeContext: reminiscing about a formative and awesome moment from his past - builds to a self-satisfied and slightly sinister note as he finishes

Raphael_SoloScene_241.speaker: Karlach
Raphael_SoloScene_241.text: Zariel wouldn't like that much. But even I'm not so desperate to spite her I'd put the Hells in this bastard's hands.
Raphael_SoloScene_241.context: NodeContext: She's in the party when Raphael says he wants the Crown of Karsus so he can unite and rule the Hells. She's amused at the idea of spiting Zariel, but still not willing to help Raphael

Raphael_SoloScene_27.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_27.text: I'm sure all you devils will play nice once you have a new tyrant.

Raphael_SoloScene_193.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_193.text: The Hells require order to function. It is what separates us from mortals and demons.

Raphael_SoloScene_184.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_184.text: The idea of you ruling all Nine Hells doesn't fill me with joy.

Raphael_SoloScene_205.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_205.text: You think I'd ever let that happen?

Raphael_SoloScene_5.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_5.text: I think you'd make a fantastic Archdevil Supreme.

Raphael_SoloScene_16.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_16.text: You're too kind. And extremely insightful.
Raphael_SoloScene_16.context: NodeContext: with a light mocking bow

Raphael_SoloScene_18.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_18.text: With the Crown, I would impose perfect order. Unity. Efficiency. Control. My kingdom would control its borders, and stay within them.

Raphael_SoloScene_148.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_148.text: Why haven't you got hold of the Crown already?

Raphael_SoloScene_98.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_98.text: It was stolen from right under my nose, all those centuries ago.

Raphael_SoloScene_38.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_38.text: What makes you think you'd succeed in using the Crown where Karsus couldn't?

Raphael_SoloScene_7.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_7.context: NodeContext: a sudden flare of rage

Raphael_SoloScene_244.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_244.context: NodeContext: regaining his composure after shouting the previous line

Raphael_SoloScene_42.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_42.text: If you don't fail, how come you didn't get hold of the Crown way back when?

Raphael_SoloScene_139.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_139.text: What's your plan? Beat up all the other devils?

Raphael_SoloScene_29.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_29.text: Why didn't you take the Crown there and then?

Raphael_SoloScene_259.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_259.text: The archdevil Mephistopheles snatched up the Crown and squirrelled it away in one of his vaults. He's naught more than a frigid archivist.
Raphael_SoloScene_259.context: NodeContext: annoyance with Mephistopheles through this next monologue - reminiscing again

Raphael_SoloScene_17.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_17.text: So much power and potential kept inert. He made a miracle into a museum piece.
Raphael_SoloScene_17.context: NodeContext: annoyance with Mephistopheles through this next monologue - reminiscing again

Raphael_SoloScene_188.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_188.text: I raged - but only for a decade or so - then I waited, ever-watching, for more than a thousand years, for a mistake, a mishap, a misadventure.
Raphael_SoloScene_188.context: NodeContext: he's being droll about raging for a decade

Raphael_SoloScene_41.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_41.text: And these Chosen who have caused you so much trouble accidentally did me a favour.
Raphael_SoloScene_41.context: NodeContext: emphasis on Chosen is emphasising his contempt for them - they're beneath him

Raphael_SoloScene_21.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_21.text: They brought the Crown back into play.

Raphael_SoloScene_35.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_35.text: It must really annoy you that some mortals managed to steal the Crown when you couldn't.

Raphael_SoloScene_200.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_200.text: Yes. It does. Especially when I see what a bloody mess they've made of their whole scheme.
Raphael_SoloScene_200.context: NodeContext: Annoyed - but tight-lipped and keeping his fury under control

Raphael_SoloScene_245.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_245.text: How did they come to have the Crown?

Raphael_SoloScene_142.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_142.text: Through the aid of a diabolist, somebody capable of opening a portal to the Hells. Deep in the Hells.

Raphael_SoloScene_96.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_96.text: They must have raided Mephistopheles' vault. Impressive, I must admit.
Raphael_SoloScene_96.context: NodeContext: begrudging admiration for people he thinks of as being beneath him

Raphael_SoloScene_222.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_222.text: If you don't kill them, the elder brain will. It doesn't have feelings in the way you'd understand them - but it seems rather angry.
Raphael_SoloScene_222.context: NodeContext: amused by his final statement

Raphael_SoloScene_208.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_208.text: It is inevitable. When you destroy the brain - and you will, because you must - the Crown will be yours for the taking.

Raphael_SoloScene_123.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_123.text: And when that moment comes, you give the Crown to me. In exchange, I give you the Hammer now.

Raphael_SoloScene_54.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_54.text: *A simple transaction, it seems, but it's more than that - he's offering you an alternative to the mind flayer in your head.*

Raphael_SoloScene_30.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_30.text: *Take Raphael's deal, and you could break Orpheus from his prison and bleed him dry. But what would become of your protection from the Absolute?*

Raphael_SoloScene_189.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_189.text: *And if you take the deal, you'll have to fulfil it. You'll have to deliver the Crown of Karsus to the Devil himself.*

Raphael_SoloScene_31.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_31.text: *He claims his ambition is to unite the Hells. But can he be trusted to stop there? Do you trust him more than you trust the Emperor?*

Raphael_SoloScene_249.speaker: Lae'zel
Raphael_SoloScene_249.text: Tsk'va. We should do as the devil asks. The Prince of the Comet must rise again.

Raphael_SoloScene_195.speaker: Lae'zel
Raphael_SoloScene_195.text: Tsk'va. We should do as the devil asks. I cannot slay Orpheus if I cannot break him free.

Raphael_SoloScene_109.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_109.text: The Prince of the Comet must rise again. I accept your bargain.

Raphael_SoloScene_37.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_37.text: I can't believe I'm doing this again, but I accept your deal, fiend.

Raphael_SoloScene_2.context: NodeContext: Player offers to sign a deal with Raphael.

Raphael_SoloScene_172.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_172.context:
CinematicNodeContext: he gestures to a contract on the table
[MK] - This has now been update to a floating contract for ease of authoring and animation

Raphael_SoloScene_165.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_165.text: You'll find everything is in order.

Raphael_SoloScene_239.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_239.text: The moment I have your signature, you will have the means to free Orpheus - the Hammer.

Raphael_SoloScene_11.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_11.text: You guarantee the Crown will be mine once the brain is defeated. And I swear that I will never use the Crown to dominate a mortal.

Raphael_SoloScene_166.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_166.text: Perfect. One more rhyme, for old times' sake.
Raphael_SoloScene_166.context: CinematicNodeContext: [MK] - Player takes and signs the contract before line is delivered - Anim re-use

Raphael_SoloScene_115.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_115.text: The master was slain within his own house.
Raphael_SoloScene_115.context: NodeContext: reciting the end of a poem

Raphael_SoloScene_114.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_114.text: They dined on him both, the cat and the mouse.
Raphael_SoloScene_114.context: NodeContext: reciting the end of a poem

Raphael_SoloScene_57.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_57.text: The Hammer is yours. You will find yourself in Orpheus' presence before the end comes - when you do, shatter the chains that hold him.

Raphael_SoloScene_194.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_194.text: Be sure to keep the Hammer safe until then. Your survival depends on it.

Raphael_SoloScene_120.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_120.text: And I'll keep your contract safe, in my House of Hope.

Raphael_SoloScene_112.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_112.text: And our deal depends on your contract. I'll keep it safe for you, in my House of Hope.

Raphael_SoloScene_36.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_36.text: For my part, I'll keep your contract safe and secure in my house.

Raphael_SoloScene_66.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_66.text: I'll be seeing you. And when I do - we dine.
Raphael_SoloScene_66.context: NodeContext: With a smile - we just made a deal with him, and he's very pleased

children.speaker: Gale
children.text: Wherever this 'House of Hope' is, we need to go there immediately and destroy that contract. We must speak with Helsik. Only a diabolist will know the way.
children.context: NodeContext: Urgent, not waiting for a reply
children.speaker: Gale
children.text: Wherever this 'House of Hope' is, we need to go there immediately and destroy that contract. We must speak with Helsik - she's the only one who can show us the way.
children.speaker: Gale
children.text: Wherever this 'House of Hope' is, we need to go there immediately and destroy that contract. We must speak with Korrilla. If anyone knows the way, it will be her.
children.speaker: Gale
children.text: Wherever this 'House of Hope' is, we need to go there immediately and destroy that contract. We must find a diabolist. Only one well-versed in devilry will know the way.
children.speaker: Narrator
children.text: *The ink has barely dried, yet you feel a growing disquiet at what exactly you just signed. Perhaps a diabolist can offer some comfort. Or a way out... for a devil's bargain is a hard one to break.*

Raphael_SoloScene_147.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_147.text: What happens if I don't give you the Crown when the time comes?

Raphael_SoloScene_103.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_103.text: I will come to collect. If you refuse to give me the Crown, I collect your souls instead.
Raphael_SoloScene_103.context: NodeContext: a simple declaration of fact - not a threat

Raphael_SoloScene_201.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_201.text: And then we all gather in the House of Hope - me dressed in my finest silks, you, skinless, hanging from a hook - to watch as your world dies.
Raphael_SoloScene_201.context: NodeContext: relishing how uncomfortable and afraid he's making us

Raphael_SoloScene_215.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_215.text: I will find another way. Your bargain is worthless.

Raphael_SoloScene_257.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_257.text: I won't stop you. But time is running out, so don't stay away for long.

Raphael_SoloScene_39.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_39.text: If you see reason, I'll be here, waiting, right up to the moment the world ends.
Raphael_SoloScene_39.context: NodeContext: He's got all the time in the world - nonchalant, despite the gravity of the statement

Raphael_SoloScene_176.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_176.text: I agree to the deal. Where do I sign?

Raphael_SoloScene_91.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_91.text: I'd rather destroy the Crown than risk it falling into the wrong hands again.

Raphael_SoloScene_15.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_15.text: How short-sighted. Much better to put it into the right hands - hands that will ensure it is removed from this world.

Raphael_SoloScene_80.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_80.text: And it's the only way you can ensure that you remain part of this world.

Raphael_SoloScene_107.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_107.text: You were very amenable helping with Cazador. We do well, working together.

Raphael_SoloScene_100.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_100.text: I'd rather eat the Crown and shit it out than see it on your head.

Raphael_SoloScene_46.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_46.text: I'll control the Crown myself once I have the Netherstones.

Raphael_SoloScene_167.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_167.text: Ha. Ha ha ha. Ha ha ha ha ha.
Raphael_SoloScene_167.context: CinematicNodeContext: laughter builds - he finds your comment ridiculousNodeContext: laughter builds - he finds your comment ridiculous

Raphael_SoloScene_138.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_138.text: Oh - I'm sorry. You were serious? The Crown has laid low all who attempt to harness its power - archwizards, emperors, gods.
Raphael_SoloScene_138.context: NodeContext: after laughing at us - still very amused, but also incredulous

Raphael_SoloScene_34.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_34.text: A worthless bargain. I will find my own way.

Raphael_SoloScene_164.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_164.text: *You could free Orpheus, the future of the Githyanki Empire, if you take Raphael's deal. And with Orpheus free, you would have no need to rely on the Emperor.*

Raphael_SoloScene_0.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_0.text: *Take Raphael's deal, and you could free Orpheus. With Orpheus free, you would have no need to rely on the Emperor.*

Raphael_SoloScene_235.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_235.text: *But there's no guarantee that Orpheus would be on your side.*

Raphael_SoloScene_133.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_133.text: What makes you so sure I'll get the Crown?

Raphael_SoloScene_152.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_152.text: I'll take the Crown and use its power myself.

Raphael_SoloScene_94.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_94.text: *The Crown of Karsus? The word of a devil counts for little, but in the written word you may yet find proof. Your trip to Sorcerous Sundries is more urgent than ever.*

Raphael_SoloScene_78.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_78.text: I'd be insane to give such a powerful artefact to a devil.

Raphael_SoloScene_225.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_225.text: Better to have it in my hands - and far from your precious world - than in the hands of the gods and monsters that fight over this city's soul.
Raphael_SoloScene_225.context: NodeContext: bargaining mode - he's negotiating now. Rising intensity

Raphael_SoloScene_163.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_163.text: Then you will die, along with every other soul in this city.

Raphael_SoloScene_151.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_151.text: Maybe I'll reconsider - but why are you so eager to get your claws on the crown?

Raphael_SoloScene_175.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_175.text: I will save every soul in the city, with a clear heart.

Raphael_SoloScene_69.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_69.text: I'm going to prove you wrong, devil.

Raphael_SoloScene_73.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_73.context: NodeContext: Smiling - he really will enjoy this.

Raphael_SoloScene_136.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_136.text: I'm willing to take the risk and put my faith in the company I keep.

Raphael_SoloScene_127.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_127.text: I will find another way. Your bargain is worthless.

Raphael_SoloScene_209.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_209.text: You'll turn on each other before this is done. Mark my words.
Raphael_SoloScene_209.context: NodeContext: amused by the thought of the players killing one another

Raphael_SoloScene_93.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_93.text: I'm a devil now, because a devil played me for a fool. You will not sway me.

Raphael_SoloScene_159.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_159.text: Just tell me what you want.

Raphael_SoloScene_256.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_256.text: I'm not bargaining with you, Raphael.

Raphael_SoloScene_76.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_76.text: No more contracts. Mizora brought me enough trouble.

Raphael_SoloScene_219.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_219.text: I'm not asking you to bargain. I'm asking you to save your soul.

Raphael_SoloScene_203.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_203.text: I'll be taking that. Right now.

Raphael_SoloScene_9.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_9.text: Sounds too good to be true.

Raphael_SoloScene_183.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_183.text: Good and truth rarely go hand in hand, but in this case, they are happy bedfellows. And we can be, too.

Raphael_SoloScene_13.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_13.text: I swear to you - I have the solution to your problem.

Raphael_SoloScene_125.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_125.text: It's very convenient that you have exactly what I need.

Raphael_SoloScene_74.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_74.text: Isn't it just? And it's even more convenient that you can give me exactly what I want in return.

Raphael_SoloScene_213.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_213.text: Orpheus' guards tried to kill me - he's dangerous.

Raphael_SoloScene_229.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_229.text: To illithids, yes. But despite your reckless embrace of the parasite and recent mutations, you're no mind flayer. Not yet.

Raphael_SoloScene_218.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_218.text: Orpheus would gladly execute the Emperor.

Raphael_SoloScene_171.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_171.text: To illithids, yes. He would gladly execute the Emperor.

Raphael_SoloScene_240.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_240.text: But to you, he will be a friend. After all, you're at war with an elder brain.

Raphael_SoloScene_236.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_236.text: All the evidence I've seen suggests Orpheus is my enemy, and the Emperor my ally.

Raphael_SoloScene_104.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_104.text: The Emperor is the only reason I'm still alive.

Raphael_SoloScene_63.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_63.text: No - Orpheus is the only reason you're still alive. The Emperor is abusing the gith for its own ends.
Raphael_SoloScene_63.context: NodeContext: trying to make a child understand something simple that they simply cannot grasp

Raphael_SoloScene_173.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_173.text: And it's doing the same to you. You're nothing more than the beast of burden that will transport it to the elder brain.
Raphael_SoloScene_173.context: NodeContext: trying to make a child understand something simple that they simply cannot grasp

Raphael_SoloScene_75.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_75.text: Fine - how do I free him?

Raphael_SoloScene_71.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_71.text: I don't want any part of this - the Emperor is my lover.

Raphael_SoloScene_49.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_49.text: I have seen all the torments of the Hells in lurid detail - none compare to the image you just conjured.
Raphael_SoloScene_49.context: NodeContext: the 'image' is a person having sex with a mindflayer. He finds it disgusting

Raphael_SoloScene_212.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_212.text: If I'd realised you were so gullible, I'd have tricked you into selling your soul for a pocketful of beans when we first met.

Raphael_SoloScene_150.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_150.text: To the Emperor, you are nothing more than a beast of burden - one that will transport it to the elder brain.

Raphael_SoloScene_216.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_216.text: An ox requires food and the occasional beating to keep it moving. You are simpler - the Emperor's words serve as both carrot and stick.
Raphael_SoloScene_216.context: NodeContext: trying to make a child understand something simple that they simply cannot grasp

Raphael_SoloScene_169.speaker: Narrator
Raphael_SoloScene_169.text: *Perhaps it is true that Orpheus would ally with you against the elder brain, but if he proves uncooperative once free, you may have to kill him.*

Raphael_SoloScene_149.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_149.text: It's worth taking the risk. How do I free Orpheus?

Raphael_SoloScene_177.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_177.text: I'm convinced. Tell me how to free Orpheus.

Raphael_SoloScene_105.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_105.text: Why would I want to free him?

Raphael_SoloScene_6.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_6.text: I suppose you'd rather suck on the Emperor's tentacles 'til the end of your days?
Raphael_SoloScene_6.context: NodeContext: disgusted and amused by the player

Raphael_SoloScene_129.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_129.text: Orpheus is your only hope of surviving this horror show without devolving into an illithid.

Raphael_SoloScene_56.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_56.text: To you, he will be a friend. After all, you're at war with an elder brain.

Raphael_SoloScene_170.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_170.text: Clever. But when we first met, you promised me a cure - this isn't a cure.

Raphael_SoloScene_20.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_20.text: I'd ask you to be patient, but you've been patient enough. Now is the time to speak plain.

Raphael_SoloScene_58.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_58.text: I'm not scared of that creature. Not when Bhaal himself has hooked his eyes on me.

Raphael_SoloScene_134.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_134.text: Oh, come. It's the reason you're in this predicament. And I'm your only way out of it. Indulge me, and at least hear me out.

Raphael_SoloScene_116.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_116.text: I feel... empty. What did you do?

Raphael_SoloScene_43.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_43.text: The tadpole is slumbering... and my blood isn't boiling.

Raphael_SoloScene_146.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_146.text: I gave you back your privacy by shutting that illithid in your pocket out of your mind. It can't hear us.
Raphael_SoloScene_146.context: NodeContext: pleased - he just did something we thought was impossible

Raphael_SoloScene_22.speaker: Player
Raphael_SoloScene_22.text: Another party trick. Show me something real.

Raphael_SoloScene_198.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_198.text: That was no party trick. Somebody's missing - can't you tell? That illithid you keep in your pocket can't hear us anymore.
Raphael_SoloScene_198.context: NodeContext: maintaining an air of mystery until the final phrase - like a stage magician revealing that his 'trick' is real magic

Raphael_SoloScene_178.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_178.text: Charming as you are, you're a little too empty-headed for my tastes. Send your companion to see me - the one with the passenger in their skull.

Raphael_SoloScene_162.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_162.text: And you, Lae'zel of K'liir, want to free the forgotten prince, do you not? Or, perhaps - to kill him?
Raphael_SoloScene_162.context: InternalNodeContext: Speaking to Lae'zel in slot 2NodeContext: keh-LEAR, Lae'zel's home creche

Raphael_SoloScene_87.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_87.text: Whichever way the wind blows you, you'll need the Orphic Hammer in hand.
Raphael_SoloScene_87.context: InternalNodeContext: Speaking to Lae'zel in slot 2

Raphael_SoloScene_101.speaker: Raphael
Raphael_SoloScene_101.text: After all - you can't take a blade to the prince while the illithid still binds him.
